posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked:
If you‚Äôre using any path planning, check to make sure you‚Äôre using the correct Field Length. Depending on what authority you ask you get different answers.

(WRONG) The initial WPIlib release had a typo and reported 16.451 meters (instead of 16.541 that is more accurate) allwpilib/apriltag/src/main/native/resources/edu/wpi/first/apriltag/2024-crescendo.json at 1e168f363e23c42bde8b39e75765bb2eb81f97b2 ¬∑ wpilibsuite/allwpilib ¬∑ GitHub

Current release of WPILib reports 16.541 allwpilib/apriltag/src/main/native/resources/edu/wpi/first/apriltag/2024-crescendo.json at main ¬∑ wpilibsuite/allwpilib ¬∑ GitHub

Choreo Choreo/choreolib/src/main/java/com/choreo/lib/ChoreoTrajectoryState.java at main ¬∑ SleipnirGroup/Choreo ¬∑ GitHub has a length that is 0.515 millimeters longer than WPILib. private static final double FIELD_WIDTH_METERS = 16.5410515; and they call it WIDTH and not length. ???

PathPlanner pathplanner/pathplannerlib/src/main/java/com/pathplanner/lib/util/GeometryUtil.java at main ¬∑ mjansen4857/pathplanner ¬∑ GitHub FIELD_LENGTH = 16.54 Value is defined multiple places, all as 16.54, but is a full 1mm shorter than WPILib.

OnShape CAD Onshape length: 16541.0515 mm = 16.5410515 m  (need to hover over the number in millimiters to get the non-rounded number) Measuring from driver station wall to driver station wall. Presumably this is where choreo got the number.

The only wrong value here is 1. as ¬± 1mm isn‚Äôt going to make a difference in your auto path, and it‚Äôs not like the field will be within a 1mm tolerance.

Anyone have a plan for checking AptilTag locations? I‚Äôm wanting a spreadsheet of measurements to double check the WPILib JSON file. Not sure what to accept as ground truth. WPILib field layout JSON or the OnShape CAD. Is there a SolidWorks model as well?

posts.name: Eric Schaefer
posts.cooked: So my team is having an issue with the width of the field dimension. Well not the dimension but the physical driving aspect of it.  When we use path planner and we draw our paths to where we want the robot to drive we are off by roughly .4 of a meter. If we put our points y dimension -.4 we are exaclty where we need to be. Any ideas???

posts.name: Tyler Veness
posts.cooked:
randomstring:

Choreo Choreo/choreolib/src/main/java/com/choreo/lib/ChoreoTrajectoryState.java at main ¬∑ SleipnirGroup/Choreo ¬∑ GitHub has a length that is 0.515 millimeters longer than WPILib. private static final double FIELD_WIDTH_METERS = 16.5410515; and they call it WIDTH and not length. ???

Thanks for pointing that out. I‚Äôve made a PR fixing that: Fix field length variable name by calcmogul ¬∑ Pull Request #348 ¬∑ SleipnirGroup/Choreo ¬∑ GitHub

link_counts.title: Fix field length variable name by calcmogul ¬∑ Pull Request #348 ¬∑ SleipnirGroup/Choreo ¬∑ GitHub

posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked: Definitely not related to this, but‚Ä¶ 0.4 meters is roughly 16", or about half a robot width/length. Are you measuring to the center of the robot or the bumper? PathPlanner will be mapping the center of the robot.

posts.name: Alexander Hamilton
posts.cooked:
randomstring:

Presumably this is where choreo got the number.

Hey, ‚ÄúChoreo‚Äù here. I did get that number using that method

posts.name: Eric Schaefer
posts.cooked: Center of the robot.  It is perfect on the x just not on the y values.  For some reason, I have had some other people look at it and we cant figure it out either.
